    • CloudAudit Definitions
    • Cloudtrail
      • Service Disabled
    • EC2
      • TCP port open
      • Host IP added to Security Group
      • Security group specifies a port range
      • Security group unrestricted traffic
    • ELB
      • Old ELB SSL policy
    • IAM
      • Active user Access Key not rotated
      • Passwords not set to expire
      • Inactive user Access Key not rotated
      • Passwords policy doesn't exist
      • Multiple active access keys
      • MFA not enabled
      • Root MFA not enabled
      • Root user has active password
      • Users can reuse old passwords
      • Active root Access Key
      • Unused or empty IAM group
      • Account using inline policies
    • RDS
      • RDS is Publicly Accessible
      • RDS short backup retention
      • RDS no automatic upgrades
    • Redshift
      • Cluster data not encrypted
      • Redshift connections not SSL
      • User activity logging disabled
      • Automatic upgrades not enabled
      • Cluster is publicly accessible
      • Redshift TCP port open
    • S3
      • All users can list bucket
      • All users can write to bucket
      • All users can change bucket permissions
      • All AWS users can read bucket
      • All AWS users can change bucket permissions
      • All AWS users can write to bucket
      • Bucket logging not enabled
      • Bucket policy uses IP addresses
      • Bucket policy world All permissions
      • Bucket policy world can Delete
      • Bucket policy world can Get
      • Bucket policy world can List
      • Bucket policy world can Put

    Account using inline policies

    User account is using custom inline policies versus using IAM group managed policies.
    Edit me

    Details

    Different types of policies are for different use cases. In most cases, we recommend that you use managed policies instead of inline policies. Managed policies provide the following features: Reusability, Central change management, Versioning and rolling back, and Delegating permissions management.” http://docs.aws.amazon.com/IAM/latest/UserGuide/access_policies_managed-vs-inline.html#choosing-managed-or-inline

    Suggested Action

    Switch all inline policies to IAM Managed Policies then assign policies to identities (users, groups, and roles).

    Creating a new IAMs policy

    Additional information

    Using IAM, you apply permissions to IAM users, groups, and roles (which are referred to as principal entities) by creating policies. You can create two types of IAM, or identity-based policies:

    Managed policies – Standalone policies that you can attach to multiple users, groups, and roles in your AWS account. Managed policies apply only to identities (users, groups, and roles) - not resources. You can use two types of managed policies: AWS managed policies – Managed policies that are created and managed by AWS. If you are new to using policies, we recommend that you start by using AWS managed policies. Customer managed policies – Managed policies that you create and manage in your AWS account. Using customer managed policies, you have more precise control over your policies than when using AWS managed policies.

    Inline policies – Policies that you create and manage, and that are embedded directly into a single user, group, or role. Resource-based policies are another form of inline policy. Resource-based policies are not discussed here. For more information about resource-based policies, see Identity-Based (IAM) Permissions and Resource-Based Permissions.
    http://docs.aws.amazon.com/IAM/latest/UserGuide/access_policies_managed-vs-inline.html

    Choosing Managed or Inline Policies
